docs.snippet: The shares of Microchip Technology Inc. fell more than 20 percent yesterday after the company warned that earnings and revenue would be lower than expected  in its fourth quarter, ending on March 31. The shares fell $7.50, to $28.50, in  Nasdaq tr...
docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of Microchip Technology Inc. fell more than 20 percent yesterday after the company warned that earnings and revenue would be lower than expected in its fourth quarter, ending on March 31. The shares fell $7.50, to $28.50, in Nasdaq trading. Microchip, based in Chandler, Ariz., makes microcontrollers for cellular telephones and computer pointing devices and other products. The company said many of its customers were delaying orders because of high inventory levels. At least two brokerage houses downgraded the company's stock, and some analysts reduced their earnings estimates by 5 percent to 10 percent for the year that ends in March 1997.

docs.snippet: A private company that took over 35 inspection stations for the Division of Motor Vehicles began operations yesterday.    The switch to the company, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, was part of a process that will ultimately bring majo...
docs.abstract: Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, private company that took over 35 inspection stations for New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles, begins operations (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A private company that took over 35 inspection stations for the Division of Motor Vehicles began operations yesterday. The switch to the company, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, was part of a process that will ultimately bring major changes to New Jersey drivers, including inspections every other year and a much tougher emissions test.

docs.snippet: Seagate Technology Inc. said today that it was pushing out its chief executive, Alan F. Shugart, a pioneer in the invention of the computer disk drive, and replacing him with Stephen J. Luczo, the company's president.    Seagate, the world's bigge...
docs.abstract: Seagate Technology Inc is pushing out its chief executive, Alan F Shugart, and replacing him with Stephen J Luczo, company's president (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Seagate Technology Inc. said today that it was pushing out its chief executive, Alan F. Shugart, a pioneer in the invention of the computer disk drive, and replacing him with Stephen J. Luczo, the company's president. Seagate, the world's biggest maker of disk drives, said it had asked Mr. Shugart, one of its founders, to retire so the company could concentrate on turning around its fortunes after a difficult year.

headline.main: Seagate Is Ousting Its Chief Executive

docs.snippet: A Paris court faces the ticklish question on Monday of whether French laws aimed at promoting the French language and culture can reach into cyberspace. The court is to hold a hearing on a legal challenge by two private French groups, Defense of t...
docs.abstract: Court in Paris will hold hearing on legal challenge by two private French groups against Internet site set up by French campus of Georgia Institute of Technology; at issue is fact that site is written in English (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Paris court faces the ticklish question on Monday of whether French laws aimed at promoting the French language and culture can reach into cyberspace. The court is to hold a hearing on a legal challenge by two private French groups, Defense of the French Language and Future of the French Language, against an Internet site set up by the French campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology, which is written in English. Officials of the school say the Web site -- www.georgiatech-metz.fr -- is in English because its courses are taught in English and its students must be fluent in English.

docs.snippet: ''DID I wear that?'' Carol Burnett asked, pointing at a mannequin wearing an outlandish yellow sequined jump suit topped off by a sequin daisy and with a long slit up the leg.     ''No, that's Mitzi Gaynor,'' replied Bob Mackie, the designer of th...
docs.abstract: a night out with: bob mackie
docs.lead_paragraph: ''DID I wear that?'' Carol Burnett asked, pointing at a mannequin wearing an outlandish yellow sequined jump suit topped off by a sequin daisy and with a long slit up the leg. ''No, that's Mitzi Gaynor,'' replied Bob Mackie, the designer of the daisy outfit -- as well as 135 others, plus 19 more on Barbie dolls -- at the opening party Thursday night for ''Unmistakably Mackie,'' his retrospective at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. (The show's title is also the name of a new tie-in book and a tie-in fragrance.)

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Bob Mackie; A Certain Sparkle Lights a Memory Lane

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your March 28 editorial on the report of gender bias at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says  some salary differences between men and women ''can be explained by seniority, academic disciplines and life-style choices am...
docs.abstract: Sumitra Shah letter on March 28 editorial on report of gender bias at Massachusetts Institute of Technology
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your March 28 editorial on the report of gender bias at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says some salary differences between men and women ''can be explained by seniority, academic disciplines and life-style choices among women encumbered with family responsibilities.'' The decision to have children is not a life-style choice. Societies will not be able to reproduce themselves if women are forced to choose to have careers at the expense of bringing up families.

docs.snippet: Jennifer Ciambrone was taking her  Toyota Celica for its annual inspection here Thursday morning when she noticed something odd about the staff. ''They were actually nice and said hello to me,'' Ms. Ciambrone of Oceanport said. ''They usually don'...
docs.abstract: Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group of California takes over operations of 35 vehicle inspection stations in New Jersey; motorists report pleasant change in demeanor of employees; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Ciambrone was taking her Toyota Celica for its annual inspection here Thursday morning when she noticed something odd about the staff. ''They were actually nice and said hello to me,'' Ms. Ciambrone of Oceanport said. ''They usually don't say 'boo.' They just grunt at you.'' Robert Zeller of Shrewsbury, who received a sticker for a one-year extension, said, ''You always went in there with your heart pounding, wondering if you would make it out the other end.'' This time, he said, ''I had a three-minute wait, a clear line through, and there was a very nice person on the other end.''

headline.main: Privately, Inspections Seem to Be Less of a Hassle

docs.snippet: The State Department of Transportation notified 3,800 of its workers yesterday that some of them could be laid off in November after the state turns over the operation of 35 motor vehicle inspection stations to a private company.    Under the term...
docs.abstract: New Jersey State Department of Transportation notifies 3,800 of its workers that some of them could be laid off in November after state turns over operation of 35 motor vehicle inspection stations to private company, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department of Transportation notified 3,800 of its workers yesterday that some of them could be laid off in November after the state turns over the operation of 35 motor vehicle inspection stations to a private company. Under the terms of a $362 million contract with the state, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group of Pasadena, Calif., must offer jobs to 482 state employees who had been conducting the inspections, said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for the department's Division of Motor Vehicles. Layoff notices went out to 3,800 department employees because workers with less seniority could be affected, he said.

headline.main: Motor Vehicles Workers Receive Layoff Warning

docs.snippet: Applied Cellular Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to hire an investment banker to help it explore ways to increase its share price, including mergers and joint ventures. The company, which builds wireless phone systems, said it was i...
docs.abstract: Applied Cellular Technology Inc plans to hire investment banker to help it explore ways to increase its share price, including mergers and joint ventures (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Applied Cellular Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to hire an investment banker to help it explore ways to increase its share price, including mergers and joint ventures. The company, which builds wireless phone systems, said it was interviewing bankers and expects to choose one within six weeks, with a strategy to be mapped by October. Shares of the company, which is based in Nixa, Mo., rose 90.625 cents, to $4.59375, in Nasdaq trading, where the company's current market capitalization is about $102 million.

headline.main: APPLIED CELLULAR SEEKS PLAN TO INCREASE STOCK PRICE

docs.snippet: The disk drive maker Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a substantial operating loss in its second quarter as lower prices for its goods and slack demand hurt revenues much more than the company had originally expected...
docs.abstract: Seagate Technology Inc says it expects to post substantial operating loss in its second quarter as lower prices for its goods and slack demand hurt revenues much more than company had originally expected (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The disk drive maker Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a substantial operating loss in its second quarter as lower prices for its goods and slack demand hurt revenues much more than the company had originally expected. The announcement was the second warning from Seagate about its second quarter, which ended Jan. 2. It had earlier predicted marginal profits for the quarter, and analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation were looking for the company to post earnings of 3 cents a share. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said its second-quarter revenues from drive operations were significantly less than previously anticipated. The company made its announcement after its shares fell $1.25 each, to $20.625.

headline.main: SEAGATE EXPECTS TO POST A SUBSTANTIAL OPERATING LOSS
